column2: absolute zero is the temperature at which the particles of matter (molecules and atoms) are at their lowest energy points. It is a common misconception that at absolute zero particles lose all energy and stop moving. This
column4: is false. In quantum physics there is something called zero point energy
column5: which means that even after all the energy that can be extrapolated from particles is extrapolated
column6: particles still have some energy. This is due to the Heisenberg Principle of Uncertainty
column7: which states that the more you know about a particles position
column8: the less you know about it's momentum
column10: you cannot have a particle that is stopped
column11: because then you would know both its exact position and momentum. In practice
column14: much like reaching the speed of light
column15: the amount of energy required is too vast. Some people have created temperatures very close to absolute zero: the record temperature was 100 pK (one hundred picokelvin
column16: equal to 10-10 kelvin) above absolute zero. Even getting close to absolute zero is difficult because anything that touches an object being cooled near absolute zero would give heat to the objects.
